results.title: The Olympic flame and the peace fire
results.brief_description:
The year 2000 saw water in the normally dry Lake Eyre. Life flourished there. But nearby, uranium mining was poisoning the land, and sucking millions of litres of artesian water each day. If Sydney was the headquarters for the Olympic Games, the shores of Lake Eyre was the base for a group of peace activists.
In June of that year, two very different journeys commenced. One was the journey of the Olympic Torch and the other was a walk by group of people carrying a sacred fire with them, who wanted to spread the message of peace.
This documentary explores the beginnings of both journeys. It presents the start of the Olympic Torch relay through another perspective and shows what wasn’t seen by a global Olympic audience - a walk by a small group of people from the the shores of Lake Eyre to Sydney to raise awareness about nuclear issues and promote peace.
The decision to do some filming was made in Coober Pedy two days before the Olympic Torch Relay commenced. In an old Subaru station wagon, Melbourne-based Sam de Silva, Michael Lumsdon and ‘Fergus’ travelled to Uluru, Alice Springs and Lake Eyre Peace Camp over a period of 3 days to document the story of the Olympic Flame and the Peace Fire.
An Access News story. Voice over by Alex Kelly.

results.title: Herald Sun Occupation
results.creator_credit: Campbell Manderson, Pip Starr and SKA TV
results.brief_description: During the World Economic Forum (WEF) held in Melbourne in September 2000, a group of protesters went to the Herald Sun newspaper to voice their concern the paper’s exceptionally biased coverage of the protests outside the WEF. Screened as a news story for SKA TV’s Access News, a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.

results.title: Emu Spew
results.creator_credit: Campbell Manderson, Pip Starr and SKA TV
results.brief_description: Report on the efforts of the Adnyamathanha people, traditional landowners of the Northern Flinders Rangers to stop the Beverly Uranium Mining Project. The report also covers police action against the protestors and the unsafe method the mining company are using to extract the uranium. Produced as a news story for SKA TV’s Access News, a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.

results.title: Fortress Goolengook
results.creator_credit: Campbell Manderson, Pip Starr and SKA TV
results.brief_description: After having their camp destroyed by loggers, forest blockaders in the heart of East Gippsland’s Goolengook forest build an elaborate fortress (including drawbridge!) to ensure their safety against further attacks. Produced as a news story for SKA TV’s Access News, a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.

results.title: The Bunyip and the Green Ban
results.creator_credit: Campbell Manderson, Pip Starr and SKA TV
results.brief_description: A local report on a residents’ fight to heritage list the Gentle Bunyip, an historic house in Clifton Hill. Produced as a news story for SKA TV’s Access News, a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.

results.title: The Nuremberg Chronicle
results.creator_credit: John Frazer, Russell T Limbach and Weslyan University
results.brief_description: Explores the handsome woodcuts that illustrate the Nuremberg Chronicle - a history of the world published in 1493 - giving the account of history as it was known in 1493 from the Creation to the Final Judgement that was predicted to be coming soon. The film conveys something of people’s hopes, fears and beliefs at a time in history when old ways and ideas were changing radically.

results.title: The North of Russia
results.brief_description: A documentary, produced in a travelogue style, that looks at the country, the people, the architecture and other aspects of Northern Russia.

results.title: The New world: auto pilot
results.brief_description: The film shows a series of blind landings, made entirely by an “Auto-Pilot.” It is installed in the Trident aircraft, the first to be designed from the outset for automatic landing. From inside the aircraft, the film follows the full operation of automatic landings, and explains how the system works. There are also interviews with a test pilot, an aircraft captain and passengers

results.title: The New ship
results.creator_credit: Tony Eggleton and Department of the Navy
results.brief_description: Shows the Royal Australian Navy’s first American built vessel, the guided missile destroyer Perth, with scenes of the crew in training and at leisure in America, the delivery and commissioning ceremony.

results.title: The New councillor
results.brief_description: Through the experiences of Richards, a newly elected borough councillor, shows the varied activities of a typical councillor - the people’s relationship both with the people who elected him and the permanent officials who carry out the policy laid down by the council.
